bibl.title: John Matthews v. Henry M. White. Testimony
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington

body.p: Re-opening case of T.M Fisher, Examining Inspector JOHN MATTHEWS. Lilian Held Bourland, Reporter.

Q (Inspector Fisher) I want to get a little more detailed information from you. What was your name in the Old Country? A. My name in the Old Country was Yan Matveyeff. Q And you changed it yourself to John Matthews? A. Yes. Q You told me you were born in Ukrania? What is the name of the place in Ukrania. What is the country, provice, district, state, town? A. State of Chartkoof (?) Town of Noshkofsky (?) Q Ukrania is now a part under the Russian flag and part under the Austrian flag. A. Yes. Q What do you call your nationality? A. Ukranian. Q At that time were you an Austrian subject? A. Yes, sir, yes. Q What was the last place in that country that you lived. Did you live in any other place? A. No, my mother and father were born in that Chortkoof. Q What was the date of your birth there? A. I cannot tell you. Q How old are you now? A. I am 29 years old. Q How do you know that? A. I had my book made out by the priest when I left that country? Q A passport? Yes, I lost it in the Porkupine fire in Ontario. Q Never got another one? Never applied for one with the Consul or any one else? A. How could I, I have not been back, No, sir. Q Do you know whether there is any baptismal or birth record? A. That was all in my book given by the priest but I have lost it. Q Do you know whether it was recorded there? A. It is all changed there now. Q What was the nearest place where your Government had a recording office or something of that kind? A. That was Chortkoff. Q What was your fathers name? A. Antonio Matfeo (Matveyeff) Q Your father was born there? A. Yes. Q Do you knows your mother's maiden name - her name before she was married? A. Annie Lozarok. Q Are your parents living? A. No, sir. Q Have you any relatives in the Old Country that you know of? A. I have no written to the Old Country since I was - 15 years ago, Q Do you know whether your parents are living? A. My mother died when i was 7 and my father when I was 14. Q Are you married? A. No, sir. Q When did you leave the country? A. I left Ukrania when I was, I think about 15 years old. Q Now, you have lived in Canada for a number of years? A. I lived in Canada ever since- all my life since I came over.

Q How did you get that mining claim that you told me about your have over in Canada, if you had never became a citizen of Canada? A. In Canada if you came from England, France, or Germany, or - you could, if you were prospecting, you could go mining and prospecting. They never asked if you are a citizen or not. Q Did you ever become a citizen of Canada or not? A. No, sir, I did not. Q Wheen you entered the United States at Victoria the record shows that you stated you were a citizen of Canada, You claimed to be a Canadia citizen? A. Yes, yes, All very well. When you live in Canada, in a country 12 years, you are a Citizen, you think- Q You claimed it by reason of the length of time you lived there and not because of any papers? A. Yes, sir. Q Did you buy any property? A. Yes, I have a claim. Q Did you buy it? A. No, sir. It is a mineral claim. Q You had partners in it? A. Yes sir, Four of us. Q Have you heard from them lately? A. No, sir, and I don't want to either from this place. Q What do they call you, John Matthews or Jack Matthews? A. Just call me Jack Matthews around Canada wherever I was, with the people I was working with. Q You got that name from your name from the Old Country- Yan? A. In the Old Country I was called Yanich Matevyeff. In my passport which has been wrote by the Austrian priest- Yan Matevyeff Q The English of that would be John Matthews or Jack Matthews? A. I have always, all my life had only one name since I came to Canada, The prient said, you take this name- Jack Matthews- Priest Wooley, in Cobalt. Write to the priest and he tell you all about it. Q You never declared your intention to become a citizen of the United States? A. No, sir. You fellows could write to Cobalt Police Station and they will give you my record because I never have been in - I have been in Cobald for 9 years and I never was one in trouble, but in the registration there they have my name, where I reported once a money. They could tell you who I am. Or write a Pichartin (?) I was working or to my mines where I was working, and you find out who I am, and if I was arrested for even about 24 hours or ever in trouble, I never arrested for an hour for 13 years. That in Alaska was my first trouble.

Description: Age 28; Height 5'61/4in; weight 189 lbs; forehead, medium, face round; build heavey; hair, dark brown; nose, regular; eyes, hazel green, complexion, ruddy; marks, scar left side head, 2" over ear 1/2n long; Scar, right index finger 1 3/4" long; portion right ring finger removed,
Attest: Lilian Held Bourland, Book 1066 Transcribed February 4, 1921
